sentences.sentence: By Jason Clemens, Jake Fuss and Milagros PalaciosWhile the war in Ukraine has increased uncertainty around the world, particularly in energy markets, here at home we're quickly approaching a critical test of the Trudeau government's fiscal probity.
Ottawa will likely have more revenue - perhaps considerably more - than recently forecast when the government tables its next budget, perhaps in late March.

Finance Minister Freeland and Prime Minister Trudeau face a fiscal test - can they restrain their spending proclivities to improve federal finances given the unplanned increase in revenues?All provinces that recently updated their finances reported marked improvements in revenues.

The recent fall fiscal update(https://www.ontario.ca/page/2021-22-third-quarter-finances#section-2) from Ontario, for instance, indicated revenues would be $22.6 billion higher than forecast in last year's budget(https://budget.ontario.ca/2021/contents.html).

Alberta's 2022 Budget(https://www.alberta.ca/revenue.aspx) expects revenues to be $18.0 billion higher in 2021-22 than originally budgeted last year(https://open.alberta.ca/publications/budget-2021), thanks largely to increases in resource revenues but also higher personal and business income tax revenue.

Revenues are also up in British Columbia(https://www.bcbudget.gov.bc.ca/2022/pdf/2022_Budget_and_Fiscal_Plan.pdf) and Prince Edward Island(https://www.princeedwardisland.ca/en/information/finance/provincial-budget-operating-budget), which both recently released their 2022 budgets.While the situation in Europe remains volatile, higher oil and gas prices increase revenues to the provinces and Ottawa.
So does higher inflation, which Canadians are feeling, not only at the pumps but almost everywhere.

Unfortunately, the Trudeau government has a poor record with unexpected revenues, opting at every opportunity to increase spending rather than moving towards budget balance.Consider fiscal 2018-19 and the decisions by then-Finance Minister Bill Morneau and Prime Minister Trudeau.

As is normal, Ottawa presented a full budget(https://www.budget.gc.ca/2018/home-accueil-en.html) in the spring and an economic and fiscal update(https://www.budget.gc.ca/fes-eea/2018/docs/statement-enonce/toc-tdm-en.html) in the fall.

Between the budget and the update, revenues were $5.5 billion higher (and federal debt costs $2.5 billion lower) than budgeted, resulting in a windfall of $8.0 billion.If the government had simply continued to spend based on its plans released in the spring budget, it could have reduced the deficit from a planned $18.1 billion to roughly $10.0 billion.
Instead, though its spending plans were only months old, it increased spending by exactly $8.0 billion and the deficit came in as originally budgeted, at $18.1 billion.

Despite an extra $8.0 billion in revenue, the Trudeau government wasn't able to reduce the budgeted deficit by a single dollar.William Watson: Ideology gets a bad rap(https://financialpost.com/opinion/william-watson-ideology-gets-a-bad-rap)Opinion: For better internet, stop controlling wholesale prices(https://financialpost.com/opinion/opinion-for-better-internet-stop-controlling-wholesale-prices)Terence Corcoran: In oil crisis, where do our banks stand?

(https://financialpost.com/opinion/terence-corcoran-in-oil-crisis-where-do-our-banks-stand)Not only has the government, under both finance ministers Morneau and Freeland, demonstrated a proclivity for spending at the expense of making progress towards a balanced budget, but it seems uninterested in targeting assistance to Canadians in need, which would better control spending and the borrowing required to finance it.

For example, several recent Fraser Institute analyses(http://www.fraserinstitute.org/studies/is-the-canada-child-benefit-targeted-to-those-most-in-need) of the Canada Child Benefit (CCB), a hallmark reform of the Trudeau government, show that despite political rhetoric, increased CCB spending has largely benefited(http://www.fraserinstitute.org/studies/distribution-of-the-canada-child-benefit-by-family-type-and-income-level) middle- and even some upper-income families, rather than lower-income families.Moreover, an analysis(http://www.fraserinstitute.org/studies/federal-government-wasting-billions-on-poorly-targeted-assistance) of COVID-related programs, including CERB, CESB (CERB for students) and one-time COVID payments to seniors, concluded that up to 27.4 per cent (or $81.6 billion) of the spending was poorly targeted and provided assistance to individuals and families with questionable need.

Similarly, a recent Statistics Canada report(https://www150.statcan.gc.ca/n1/daily-quotidien/220223/dq220223c-eng.htm) found that large corporations were twice as likely as small businesses to receive the Canada Emergency Wage Subsidy (CEWS) despite the program having been enacted to target assistance(https://torontosun.com/news/national/parliaments-100b-small-business-relief-program-mostly-went-to-large-corporations-report) to small businesses.It would not be surprising, of course, if Russian aggression in Ukraine requires Ottawa to increase overall defence spending.
But these are the choices governments must make.

Does Ottawa simply spend more money (again) and make no progress in balancing the budget, or does it look at current spending to find waste, duplication and savings so its spending plans accommodate increased defence spending?In light of the revenue windfall many expect in the upcoming federal budget, if the Trudeau government adheres to the spending plan it presented in the 2021 fall update(https://www.budget.gc.ca/efu-meb/2021/report-rapport/EFU-MEB-2021-EN.pdf) (which amounts to more than $420 billion next year), it could dramatically reduce the deficit and place Canada on a realistic path towards budget balance.
However, such an approach requires spending restraint in the face of a windfall.

This is a test for the relatively new finance minister and Trudeau government more broadly: to spend or not to spend.Jason Clemens, Milagros Palacios and Jake Fuss are economists with the Fraser Institute.
